Title: Quantum complexity of integration
Affiliations: Mathematisches Institut, Universität Jena, D-07740 Jena, Ernst-Abbe-Platz 4, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Novak E., Mathematisches Institut, Universität Jena, D-07740 Jena, Ernst-Abbe-Platz 4, Germany
Abstract: It is known that quantum computers yield a speed-up for certain discrete problems. Here we want to know whether quantum computers are useful for continuous problems. We study the computation of the integral of functions from the classical Hölder classes Fk, α                             d on [0, 1]d and define γ by γ=(k+α)/d. The known optimal orders for the complexity of deterministic and (general) randomized methods are comp(Fk, α                             d, ε)ε224D;ε-1/γ and comprandom(Fk, α                             d, ε)ε-2/(1+2γ). For a quantum computer we prove compquant                             query(Fk, α                             d, ε)ε-1/(1+γ) and compquant(Fk, α                             d, ε)≤Cε-1/(1+γ)(logε-1) 1/(1+γ). For restricted Monte Carlo (only coin tossing instead of general random numbers) we prove compcoin(Fk, α                             d, ε)≤Cε-2/(1+2γ)(logε-1) 1/(1+2γ). To summarize the results one can say that •there is an exponential speed-up of quantum algorithms over deterministic (classical) algorithms, if γ is small; •there is a (roughly) quadratic speed-up of quantum algorithms over randomized classical methods, if γ is small. © 2001 Academic Press.

Title: Torsional diffusion Monte Carlo: A method for quantum simulations of proteins
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University College London, London, WC1H OAJ, 20 Gordon Street, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clary D.C., Department of Chemistry, University College London, London, WC1H OAJ, 20 Gordon Street, United Kingdom
Abstract: Coupled torsional motions in proteins were treated by extending quantum diffusion Monte Carlo method. An algorithm and program were developed by interfacing the DMC method with all-atom force fields for proteins. The method gave atomic coordinates and zero-point energy averaged over the coupled torsional motions in the quantum ground state of the protein. Application of new algorithm was made to the proteins gp41-HIV and gelsolin . Quantum dynamical effects were found to be important for the energies and geometries of typical proteins.

Authors: Berman G.P.; Borgonovi F.; Izrailev F.M.; Tsifrinovich V.I.

Title: Single-pulse preparation of the uniform superpositional state used in quantum algorithms
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: T-13 and CNLS, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica, Università Cattolica, 25121 Brescia, via Musei 41, Italy; INFN, Sezione di Pavia and INFM, Unità di Brescia, Brescia, Italy; Instituto de Fisica, Universidad Autonoma de Puebla, Puebla 72570, Apdo. Postal J-48, Mexico; IDS Department, Polytechnic University, Six Metrotech Center, Brooklyn, NY 11201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berman G.P., T-13 and CNLS, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Borgonovi F., Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica, Università Cattolica, 25121 Brescia, via Musei 41, Italy, INFN, Sezione di Pavia and INFM, Unità di Brescia, Brescia, Italy; Izrailev F.M., Instituto de Fisica, Universidad Autonoma de Puebla, Puebla 72570, Apdo. Postal J-48, Mexico; Tsifrinovich V.I., IDS Department, Polytechnic University, Six Metrotech Center, Brooklyn, NY 11201, United States
Abstract: We examine a single-pulse preparation of the uniform superpositional wave function, which includes all basis states, in a spin quantum computer. The effective energy spectrum and the errors generated by this pulse are studied in detail. We show that, in spite of the finite width of the energy spectrum bands, amplitude and phase errors can be made reasonably small. © 2001 Published by Elsevier Science B.V.

Title: Quantum optimization
Affiliations: Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, 3333 Coyote Hill Road, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States; Comp. Sci. and Eng. Department, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98105, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hogg T., Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, 3333 Coyote Hill Road, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States; Portnov D., Comp. Sci. and Eng. Department, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98105, United States
Abstract: We present a quantum algorithm for combinatorial optimization using the cost structure of the search states. Its behavior is illustrated for overconstrained satisfiability (SAT) and asymmetric traveling salesman problems (ATSP). Simulations with randomly generated problem instances show each step of the algorithm shifts amplitude preferentially towards lower cost states, thereby concentrating amplitudes into low-cost states, on average. These results are compared with conventional heuristics for these problems.

Authors: Opher M.; Silva L.O.; Dauger D.E.; Decyk V.K.; Dawson J.M.
Author full names: Opher, Merav (6602076239); Silva, Luis O. (7202197601); Dauger, Dean E. (7801377498); Decyk, Viktor K. (57206441613); Dawson, John M. (14011876200)
Title: Nuclear reaction rates and energy in stellar plasmas: The effect of highly damped modes
Affiliations: Physics and Astronomy Department, Univ. of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, United States
Authors with affiliations: Opher M., Physics and Astronomy Department, Univ. of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, United States; Silva L.O., Physics and Astronomy Department, Univ. of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, United States; Dauger D.E., Physics and Astronomy Department, Univ. of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, United States; Decyk V.K., Physics and Astronomy Department, Univ. of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, United States; Dawson J.M., Physics and Astronomy Department, Univ. of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, United States
Abstract: The effects of the highly damped modes in the energy and reaction rates in a plasma are discussed. These modes, with wave numbers k≫kD, even being only weakly excited, with less than kBT per mode, make a significant contribution to the energy and screening in a plasma. When the de Brogue wavelength is much less than the distance of closest approach of thermal electrons, a classical analysis of the plasma can be made. It is assumed, in the classical analysis, with ℏ→0, that the energy of the fluctuations ℏω≪kBT. Using the fluctuation-dissipation theorem, the spectra of fluctuations with ℏ≠0 is appreciably decreased. The decrease is mainly for the highly damped modes at high frequencies (∼0.5-3kBT). Reaction rates are enhanced in a plasma due to the screening of the reacting ions. This is taken into account by the Salpeter factor, which assumes slow motion for the ions. The implication of including the highly damped modes (with ℏ≠0) in the nuclear reaction rates in a plasma is discussed. Finally, the investigations presently done on these effects in particle simulations, with the sheet model and the multiparticle quantum simulation code are described. © 2001 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Alber G.; Mussinger M.; Delgado A.
Title: Dynamical stabilization of Grover's algorithm with embedded quantum codes
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Alber G., Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany; Mussinger M., Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany; Delgado A., Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany
Abstract: Stabilizing quantum algorithms against external perturbations and preserving quantum coherence are main challenges in the area of quantum information processing. In this contribution main ideas underlying a new class of recently proposed embedded error-correcting quantum codes are discussed. These detected-jump correcting quantum codes are capable of stabilizing distinguishable qubits against spontaneous decay provided these decay processes originate from couplings to statistically independent reservoirs. Exploiting the classical information about which qubit has been affected by the environment these embedded quantum codes minimize the number of required control measurements and recovery operations as well as redundancy. Their stabilizing properties are exemplified by applying them to Grover's quantum search algorithm.
Author Keywords: Error correction; Grover's algorithm; Jump codes; Quantum information; Spontaneous decay

Authors: Ciaramicoli G.; Marzoli I.; Tombesi P.
Title: Realization of a quantum algorithm using a trapped electron
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica and INFM, Università di Roma “La Sapienza”, Roma, 00185, Italy; Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica and INFM, Università di Camerino, Camerino, 62032, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Ciaramicoli G., Dipartimento di Fisica and INFM, Università di Roma “La Sapienza”, Roma, 00185, Italy; Marzoli I., Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica and INFM, Università di Camerino, Camerino, 62032, Italy; Tombesi P., Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica and INFM, Università di Camerino, Camerino, 62032, Italy
Abstract: The scope for realization of universal quantum logic gates using a single trapped electron was analyzed. The main area of concern was cyclotron oscillator and spin so as to use them as registers for quantum information. This provides the proof of validity of quantum logic operations and can be implemented with current technology. Deutsch algorithm was proposed to be implemented using quantized cyclotron motion and electron spin as qubits.

Title: Quantum computers and unstructured search: Finding and counting items with an arbitrarily entangled initial state
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Oh-Okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Carlini A., Department of Physics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Oh-Okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan; Hosoya A., Department of Physics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Oh-Okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan
Abstract: Grover's quantum algorithm for an unstructured search problem and the COUNT algorithm by Brassard et al. are generalized to the case when the initial state is arbitrarily and maximally entangled. This ansatz might be relevant with quantum subroutines, when the computational qubits and the environment are coupled, and in general when the control over the quantum system is partial. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V.

Title: A universal quantum network - Quantum central processing unit
Affiliations: Lab. Quant. Commun. and Quant. Comp., Univ. of Sci. and Technol. of China, Hefei 230027, China; Department of Modern Physics, Univ. of Sci. and Technol. of China, Hefei 230027, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang A.-M., Lab. Quant. Commun. and Quant. Comp., Univ. of Sci. and Technol. of China, Hefei 230027, China, Department of Modern Physics, Univ. of Sci. and Technol. of China, Hefei 230027, China
Abstract: A new construction scheme of a universal quantum network which is compatible with the known quantum gate-assembly schemes is proposed. Our quantum network is standard, easy-assemble, reusable, scalable and even potentially programmable. Moreover, we can construct a whole quantum network to implement the general quantum algorithm and quantum simulation procedure. In the above senses, it is a realization of the quantum central processing unit.

Title: International Conference on Quantum Information, ICQI 2001
Abstract: The proceedings contain 92 papers. The topics discussed include: quantum constraints on quantum error correction with laser pulses; the cost of communication; low-entanglement remote state preparation; four–photon interferometry for secure quantum key distribution; bell’s theorem without inequalities and only two distant observers; an experiment to observe macroscopic quantum coherence in an rf-SQUID; topological decomposition of composite quantum state spaces; quantum computation with femtosecond photon echo; singlet distillation from pure bipartite states; numerical simulation of decoherence-control processes in quantum computers; experimental realization of a Shor-type quantum algorithm; fidelity trade-off in quantum operations; experimental six-state quantum cryptography; and single-photon superconducting detectors for practical high-speed quantum cryptography.
Conference name: 1st International Conference on Quantum Information, ICQI 2001

Title: Effects of quantum confinement and discrete dopants in nanoscale bulk-Si nMOSFET
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Nanotechnology
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Ingegneria dell'Informazione, Università degli Studi di Pisa, Via Diotisalvi 2, Pisa, I-56122, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fiori G., Dipartimento di Ingegneria dell'Informazione, Università degli Studi di Pisa, Via Diotisalvi 2, Pisa, I-56122, Italy; Iannaccone G., Dipartimento di Ingegneria dell'Informazione, Università degli Studi di Pisa, Via Diotisalvi 2, Pisa, I-56122, Italy
Abstract: We have developed a numerical code for the three-dimensional simulation of ultrashort channel MOSFETs considering the effects due to quantum confinement of electrons at the Si/SiO2 interface. We have focused on the so-called "Well tempered" bulk-Si n-MOSFETs with channel length of 90, 50 and 25 nm proposed by D. Antoniadis. We found that the effect of quantum confinement on threshold voltage is of the order of 100 mV, and therefore justifies the effort for a quantum simulation of nanoscale MOSFETs. In addition, we have evaluated the effect of the random distribution of dopants, by simulating a large number of devices with uniform nominal doping profile but with different actual microscopic distribution of impurities, and we have computed the threshold voltage dispersion for the above mentioned devices. © 2001 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Nanotechnology; Quantum chemistry; Quantum confinement; Silicon; Threshold voltage; Doping profiles; Microscopic distribution; Nanoscale MOSFETs; Quantum simulations; Random distribution; Three dimensional simulations; Ultrashort channels; Voltage dispersion; MOSFET devices

Title: A Quantum Algorithm for Finding a Hamilton Circuit

Abstract: A quantum algorithm for solving the classical NP-complete problem - the Hamilton circuit is presented. The algorithm employs the quantum SAT and the quantum search algorithms. The algorithm is square-root faster than classical algorithm, and becomes exponentially faster than classical algorithm if nonlinear quantum mechanical computer is used.
Author Keywords: Hamilton circuit; NP-problem; Quantum algorithm

Title: Full quantum simulation, design, and analysis of Si tunnel diodes, MOS leakage and capacitance, HEMTs, and RTDs
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521-0204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lake R., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521-0204, United States
Abstract: The Nanoelectronic Engineering Modeling software (NEMO) has been used to model the quantum electron and hole transport and charge in a wide variety of material systems and semiconductor devices. This paper provides an overview of NEMO's current status, its applications, and its theoretical extensions.

Title: Grover search with pairs of trapped ions
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems, Dresden, D-01187, Nöthnitzer Street 38, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Feng M., Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems, Dresden, D-01187, Nöthnitzer Street 38, Germany
Abstract: The desired interference required for quantum computing may be modified by wave-function oscillations for the implementation of quantum algorithms [Phys. Rev. Lett. 84, 1615 (2000)]. To diminish such a detrimental effect, we propose a scheme with trapped ion pairs as qubits and apply the scheme to the Grover search. It will be shown that our scheme cannot only carry out a full Grover search, but can also meet the requirement for scalable hot-ion quantum computing. Moreover, the ion-pair qubits in our scheme are more robust against decoherence and the dissipation caused by the environment than single-particle qubits proposed before. © 2001 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Høyer P.; Neerbek J.; Shi Y.
Author full names: Høyer, Peter (56249296600); Neerbek, Jan (6506048599); Shi, Yaoyun (7404964334)
Title: Quantum complexities of ordered searching, sorting, and element distinctness
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp. Sci., University of Calgary, AB, T2N 1N4, Canada; Dept. of Comp. Sci., University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Århus C, Denmark; Dept. of Comp. Sci., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Høyer P., Dept. of Comp. Sci., University of Calgary, AB, T2N 1N4, Canada; Neerbek J., Dept. of Comp. Sci., University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Århus C, Denmark; Shi Y., Dept. of Comp. Sci., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Abstract: We consider the quantum complexities of the following three problems: searching an ordered list, sorting an un-ordered list, and deciding whether the numbers in a list are all distinct. Letting N be the number of elements in the input list, we prove a lower bound of 1/π (ln(N) 1) accesses to the list elements for ordered searching, a lower bound of ω(N logN) binary comparisons for sorting, and a lower bound of ω(pN logN) binary comparisons for element distinctness. The previously best known lower bounds are 1/12 log2(N) O(1) due to Ambainis,ω(N), and (pN), respectively. Our proofs are based on a weighted all-pairs inner product argument. In addition to our lower bound results, we give a quantum algorithm for ordered searching using roughly 0:631 log2(N) oracle accesses. Our algorithm uses a quantum routine for traversing through a binary search tree faster than classically, and it is of a nature very different from a faster algorithm due to Farhi, Goldstone, Gutmann, and Sipser. © 2011 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Index Keywords: Automata theory; Information dissemination; Quantum theory; Trees (mathematics); Binary trees; Bins; Computational linguistics; Binary search trees; Inner product; Lower bounds; Oracle access; Quantum algorithms; Quantum complexity; Binary trees; Trees (mathematics)

Authors: Asada T.; Haraguchi H.; Kitaura K.
Author full names: Asada, Toshio (36070477800); Haraguchi, Haruya (40861143500); Kitaura, Kazuo (7006953135)
Title: Simulation studies of proton transfer in N2H7+ cluster by classical ab initio Monte Carlo and quantum wave packet dynamics
Affiliations: Integrated Arts and Sciences, Osaka Prefecture University, 599-8531, Sakai-City, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Asada T., Integrated Arts and Sciences, Osaka Prefecture University, 599-8531, Sakai-City, Japan; Haraguchi H., Integrated Arts and Sciences, Osaka Prefecture University, 599-8531, Sakai-City, Japan; Kitaura K., Integrated Arts and Sciences, Osaka Prefecture University, 599-8531, Sakai-City, Japan
Abstract: The quantum effects on the proton-transfer reaction in the N2H7+ cluster has been studied using the classical ab initio Monte Carlo method and a one-dimensional model for the quantum wave packet dynamics on the ab initio MP2/6-31+G* potential energy surface. The optimized stable structure has C3v symmetry, in which the proton is bound to one NH3 molecule in such a way that the proton feels bistable potential. In contrast, we found that the proton was located at the center of two NH3 molecules with D3d symmetry due to the quantum effects of the proton kinetics. The quantum simulations indicate that the reason the experimental spectra predict N2H7+ to have a symmetric D3d structure, contrary to the ab initio results, is that the quantum effects of the proton motion is completely neglected in the previous theoretical calculations. The vibrational frequency for the N-H stretching mode which corresponds to the proton transfer is estimated to be 706.7 cm-1 by including proton quantum effects in contrast with 2100.1 cm-1 obtained by the conventional ab initio MO method for the C3v structure.

Title: Complexity measure for continuous-time quantum algorithms
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Inst. Algorithmen und Kognitive Sys., D-76 131 Karlsruhe, Am Fasanengarten 3a, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Janzing D., Inst. Algorithmen und Kognitive Sys., D-76 131 Karlsruhe, Am Fasanengarten 3a, Germany; Beth Th., Inst. Algorithmen und Kognitive Sys., D-76 131 Karlsruhe, Am Fasanengarten 3a, Germany
Abstract: The running time of a discrete algorithm simulating the evolution defined by a time-dependent Schrödinger equation with pair-interaction Hamiltonians was given by the time integral over the chromatic index of the interaction graph. As an application, it was proved that an algorithm preparing macroscopic superposition must have at least an integrated chromatic index 1/2.

Title: Quantum factoring, discrete logarithms, and the hidden subgroup problem
Affiliations: University of Bristol, United Kingdom; Department of Computer Science, University of Bristol, United Kingdom; Dept. of Computer Science, Merchant Venturers Bldg., Univ. of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1UB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jozsa R., University of Bristol, United Kingdom, Department of Computer Science, University of Bristol, United Kingdom, Dept. of Computer Science, Merchant Venturers Bldg., Univ. of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1UB, United Kingdom
Abstract: Among the most remarkable successes of quantum computation are Shor's efficient quantum algorithms for the computational tasks of integer factorization and the evaluation of discrete logarithms. This article reviews the essential ingredients of these algorithms and draws out the unifying generalization of the so-called hidden subgroup problem. © 2001 IEEE.

Title: Introduction to recent quantum algorithms
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Calgary, 2500 University Drive N.W, Calgary, T2N 1N4, AB, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Høyer P., Department of Computer Science, University of Calgary, 2500 University Drive N.W, Calgary, T2N 1N4, AB, Canada
Abstract: We discuss some of the recent progress in quantum algorithmics. We review most of the primary techniques used in proving upper and lower bounds and illustrate how to apply the techniques to a variety of problems, including the threshold function, parity, searching and sorting. We also give a set of open questions and possible future research directions. Our aim is to give a basic overview and we include suggestions to further reading. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2001.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computer science; Computers; Algorithmics; Possible futures; Quantum algorithms; Recent progress; Threshold functions; Upper and lower bounds; Quantum theory

Authors: Chi D.P.; Kim J.; Lee S.
Author full names: Chi, Dong Pyo (7102227860); Kim, Jinsoo (55868067100); Lee, Soojoon (12646572900)
Title: Initialization-free generalized Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm
Source title: Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General
Affiliations: School of Mathematical Sciences, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, South Korea; School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-744, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Chi D.P., School of Mathematical Sciences, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, South Korea; Kim J., School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-744, South Korea; Lee S., School of Mathematical Sciences, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, South Korea
Abstract: We generalize the Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm by exploiting summations of the roots of unity. The generalized algorithm distinguishes a wider class of functions promised to be either constant or many to one and onto an evenly spaced range. As previously, the generalized quantum algorithm solves this problem using a single functional evaluation. We also consider the problem of distinguishing constant and evenly balanced functions and present a quantum algorithm for this problem that does not require any initialization of an auxiliary register involved in the process of functional evaluation and after solving the problem recovers the initial state of an auxiliary register. © 2001 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Feng M.; Zhu X.-W.; Gao K.-L.; Shi L.
Title: Quantum computation by pairing trapped ultracold ions
Affiliations: Lab. Magnetic Reson. Atom. Molec. P., Wuhan Inst. of Phys. and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan 430071, China
Authors with affiliations: Feng M., Lab. Magnetic Reson. Atom. Molec. P., Wuhan Inst. of Phys. and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan 430071, China; Zhu X.-W., Lab. Magnetic Reson. Atom. Molec. P., Wuhan Inst. of Phys. and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan 430071, China; Gao K.-L., Lab. Magnetic Reson. Atom. Molec. P., Wuhan Inst. of Phys. and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan 430071, China; Shi L., Lab. Magnetic Reson. Atom. Molec. P., Wuhan Inst. of Phys. and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan 430071, China
Abstract: Superpositional wavefunction oscillations for the implementation of quantum algorithms modify the desired interference required for the quantum computation. We propose a scheme with trapped ultracold ion-pairs being qubits to diminish the detrimental effect of the wavefunction oscillations, which is applied to the two-qubit Grover's search. It can be also found that the qubits in our scheme are more robust against the decoherence caused by the environment, and the model is scalable.

Title: Quantum statistical mechanics on a quantum computer

Abstract: We describe a quantum algorithm to compute the density of states and thermal equilibrium properties of quantum many-body systems. We present results obtained by running this algorithm on a software implementation of a 21-qubit quantum computer for the case of an antiferromagnetic Heisenberg model on triangular lattices of different size.

Title: Genetic quantum algorithm and its application to combinatorial optimization problem
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Evolutionary Computation, ICEC
Affiliations: Korea Advanced Inst of Science and, Technology, Taejon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Han Kuk-Hyun, Korea Advanced Inst of Science and, Technology, Taejon, South Korea; Kim Jong-Hwan, Korea Advanced Inst of Science and, Technology, Taejon, South Korea
Abstract: This paper proposes a novel evolutionary computing method called a genetic quantum algorithm (GQA). GQA is based on the concept and principles of quantum computing such as qubits and superposition of states. Instead of binary, numeric, or symbolic representation, by adopting qubit chromosome as a representation GQA can represent a linear superposition of solutions due to its probabilistic representation. As genetic operators, quantum gates are employed for the search of the best solution. Rapid convergence and good global search capability characterize the performance of GQA. The effectiveness and the applicability of GQA are demonstrated by experimental results on the knapsack problem, which is a well-known combinatorial optimization problem. The results show that GQA is superior to other genetic algorithms using penalty functions, repair methods, and decoders.

Title: Extended cluster algorithm in quantum simulations
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Tokyo 192-0397, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Otsuka H., Department of Physics, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Tokyo 192-0397, Japan
Abstract: We propose an extension of the quantum cluster algorithm by a combined use of the Fortuin-Kasteleyn mapping and the Hubbard-Stratonovich transformation. To describe the idea, we consider the (formula presented) (formula presented) chain model and express the partition function as the sum in an extended configuration space of spins, graphs, and fields. Then it is clarified that this algorithm possesses a computationally tractable continuous-time limit and maintains virtues of the quantum cluster algorithm. Numerical simulations are performed and its applicability is demonstrated. Further, we discuss potential gains in our algorithm. © 2001 The American Physical Society.

Title: Establishment of phase between coupled Bose-Einstein condensates
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Clarendon Laboratory, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PU, Parks Road, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dunningham J.A., Clarendon Laboratory, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PU, Parks Road, United Kingdom; Burnett K., Clarendon Laboratory, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PU, Parks Road, United Kingdom
Abstract: We study how phase information is developed and transferred between Bose-Einstein condensates. First, we investigate how the phase of an output pulse of an idealized atom laser can be controlled. We then use quantum simulations to show how a relative phase between coupled systems is established by dissipation and atomic interactions. Our simulations show that each realization settles to the same relative phase between modes: for uncoupled systems the phase varies from realization to realization. We use this to demonstrate how condensates may `naturally' possess a relative phase, and to explain the phase-locking mechanism in a recent experimental demonstration of a mode-locked atom laser.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Laser mode locking; Quantum theory; Statistical mechanics; Bose-Einstein condensation; Atomic physics

Title: Quantum path-integral simulation of poly(propylene oxide)
Affiliations: Department of Applied Physics, Chalmers Univ. Technol. Goteborg U., Göteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Slabanja M., Department of Applied Physics, Chalmers Univ. Technol. Goteborg U., Göteborg, Sweden; Wahnström G., Department of Applied Physics, Chalmers Univ. Technol. Goteborg U., Göteborg, Sweden
Abstract: Quantum path-integral molecular-dynamics simulations of poly(propylene oxide) (PPO) have been performed at 300 K. We find excellent agreement for the short and intermediate range structural order as deduced from neutron diffraction measurements. The result from the quantum simulation agrees better with experimental data compared with the classical simulation using the same atomistic force field. It shows that in a detailed comparison with accurate experimental data the quantum effects of the atomic motion have to be taken into account. The results for the protonated and deuterated systems are compared and the corresponding static structure factors show very minor differences. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V.

Title: A hidden shift quantum algorithm
Source title: Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General
Affiliations: Department of Mathematical Physics, Natl. Univ. of Ireland, Maynooth, Maynooth, County Kildare, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Twamley J., Department of Mathematical Physics, Natl. Univ. of Ireland, Maynooth, Maynooth, County Kildare, Ireland
Abstract: We examine the application of quantum algorithms to the non-Abelian hidden subgroup problem and focus on the dihedral hidden subgroup problem (DHSP). Ettinger and Høyer have recently discovered an algorithm which, although efficient in the number of operations of the quantum computation, requires classical post-processing which grows exponentially with the size of the input. We first show that the DHSP can be reduced to another problem: how to efficiently estimate an unknown shift k, in a one-to-one map f : ℤM → ℤM, given two oracles which provide x → f(x), and x → f(x ⊕ k), with k and f unknown. We devise an algorithm which uses amplitude amplification to obtain an estimate for the unknown shift k in a number script O sign(√M) oracle calls.

Title: Quantum algorithms for element distinctness
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual IEEE Conference on Computational Complexity
Affiliations: CWI, Amsterdam, P.O. Box 94079, Netherlands; Université Paris-Sud, LRI, 91405 Orsay, France; NSA, Meade, MD 20755, Suite 6111, Fort George G., United States; Dept. of Comp. Sci., University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada; CNRS-LRI, UMR 8623, Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay, France

Box 94079, Netherlands
Abstract: We present several applications of quantum amplitude amplification to finding claws and collisions in ordered or unordered functions. Our algorithms generalize those of Brassard, Høyer, Tapp, and imply an O(N3/4 log N) quantum upper bound for the element distinctness problem in the comparison complexity model. This contrasts with Θ(N log N) classical complexity. We also prove a lower bound of Ω (√N) comparisons for this problem and derive bounds for a number of related problems.

Title: Implementation of a quantum algorithm to solve the Bernstein-Vazirani parity problem without entanglement on an ensemble quantum computer

Commun./Quant. Comp., University of Sci./Technol. of China, Hefei 230026, China
Abstract: A refined version of Bernstein and Vazirani's quantum algorithm was presented and implemented in a single query on ensemble quantum computer. This algorithm was demonstrated on a two-qubit nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) quantum computer. The quantum algorithm without entanglement was implemented using the nuclear spins of the two hydrogen atoms in a deuterated cytosine molecule. The concept of coherent superposition was exploited to prepare an input state which was a superposition of all possible classical inputs.

Title: Exponential gain in quantum computing of quantum chaos and localization
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, UMR 5626 du CNRS, Université Paul Sabatier, F-31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Authors with affiliations: Georgeot B., Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, UMR 5626 du CNRS, Université Paul Sabatier, F-31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France; Shepelyansky D.L., Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, UMR 5626 du CNRS, Université Paul Sabatier, F-31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Abstract: A quantum algorithm that computes the evolution of the quantum kicked rotator exponentially faster than any classical computation is presented. The algorithm shows that important systems displaying rich and complex properties like classical and quantum chaos, quantum localization, and ergodicity can be simulated exponentially faster on a quantum computer.

Authors: Milburn G.J.; Ralph T.; White A.; Knill E.; Laflamme R.
Title: Efficient linear optics quantum coputation
Affiliations: Ctr. for Quantum Computer Technology, Univ. of Queensland, St. Lucia, QLD, Australia; Los Alamos National Laboratory, MS B265, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Milburn G.J., Ctr. for Quantum Computer Technology, Univ. of Queensland, St. Lucia, QLD, Australia; Ralph T., Ctr. for Quantum Computer Technology, Univ. of Queensland, St. Lucia, QLD, Australia; White A., Ctr. for Quantum Computer Technology, Univ. of Queensland, St. Lucia, QLD, Australia; Knill E., Los Alamos National Laboratory, MS B265, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Laflamme R., Los Alamos National Laboratory, MS B265, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: Two qubit gates for photons are generally thought to require exotic materials with huge optical nonlinearities. We show here that, if we accept two qubit gates that only work conditionally, single photon sources, passive linear optics and particle detectors are sufficient for implementing reliable quantum algorithms. The conditional nature of the gates requires feed-forward from the detectors to the optical elements. Without feed forward, non-deterministic quantum computation is possible. We discuss one proposed single photon source based on the surface acoustic wave guiding of single electrons.

Title: Using fewer qubits in shor's factorization algorithm via simultaneous diophantine approximation
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Infineon Technologies, Security and ChipCard ICs, Munich, D-81609, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Seifert J.-P., Infineon Technologies, Security and ChipCard ICs, Munich, D-81609, Germany
Abstract: While quantum computers might speed up in principle certain computations dramatically, in practice, though quantum computing technology is still in its infancy. Even we cannot clearly envision at present what the hardware of that machine will be like. Nevertheless, we can be quite confident that it will be much easier to build any practical quantum computer operating on a few number of quantum bits rather than one operating on a huge number of quantum bits. It is therefore of big practical impact to use the resource of quantum bits very spare, i. e., to find quantum algorithms which use as few as possible quantum bits. Here, we present a method to reduce the number of actually needed qubits in Shor's algorithm to factor a composite number N. Exploiting the inherent probabilism of quantum computation we are able to substitute the continued fraction algorithm to find a certain unknown fraction by a simultaneous Diophantine approximation. While the continued fraction algorithm is able to find a Diophantine approximation to a single known fraction with a denominator greater than N2, our simultaneous Diophantine approximation method computes in polynomial time unusually good approximations to known fractions with a denominator of size N1+ɛ, where ɛ is allowed to be an arbitrarily small positive constant. As these unusually good approximations are almost unique we are able to recover an unknown denominator using fewer qubits in the quantum part of our algorithm. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2001.
Index Keywords: Cryptography; Factorization; Polynomial approximation; Quantum optics; Qubits; Composite numbers; Continued fraction algorithm; Diophantine approximation; Factorization algorithms; Positive constant; Quantum algorithms; Shor's algorithms; Simultaneous Diophantine approximation; Approximation algorithms

Authors: Mahesh T.S.; Dorai K.; Arvind; Kumar A.
Title: Implementing logic gates and the Deutsch-Jozsa quantum algorithm by two-dimensional NMR using spin- and transition-selective pulses
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Mahesh T.S., Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India; Dorai K., Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India; Arvind, Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India; Kumar A., Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India
Abstract: Quantum logical operations using two-dimensional NMR have recently been described using the scalar coupling evolution technique [J. Chem. Phys. 109, 10603 (1998)]. In the present paper, we describe the implementation of quantum logical operations using two-dimensional NMR, with the help of spin- and transition-selective pulses. A number of logic gates are implemented using two and three qubits with one extra observer spin. Some many-in-one gates (or Portmanteau gates) are also implemented. Toffoli gate (or AND/NAND gate) and OR/NOR gates are implemented on three qubits. The Deutsch-Jozsa quantum algorithm for one and two qubits, using one extra work qubit, has also been implemented using spin- and transition-selective pulses after creating a coherent superposition state in the two-dimensional methodology. © 2001 Academic Press.

Author full names: Cheung, Kevin K. H. (57217363250); Mosca, Michele (55046279600)
Title: Decomposing finite Abelian groups
Affiliations: Dept. Combinatorics and Optimization, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont. N2L 3G1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cheung K.K.H., Dept. Combinatorics and Optimization, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont. N2L 3G1, Canada; Mosca M., Dept. Combinatorics and Optimization, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont. N2L 3G1, Canada
Abstract: This paper describes a quantum algorithm for efficiently decomposing finite Abelian groups into a product of cyclic groups. Such a decomposition is needed in order to apply the Abelian hidden subgroup algorithm. Such a decomposition (assuming the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis) also leads to an efficient algorithm for computing class numbers (known to be at least as difficult as factoring).

Title: Quantum network optimization
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Département de Physique and Centre de Recherche sur les Propriétés Électroniques de Matériaux Avancés, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, QC, J1K 2R1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Blais A., Département de Physique and Centre de Recherche sur les Propriétés Électroniques de Matériaux Avancés, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, QC, J1K 2R1, Canada
Abstract: In many candidate designs of solid-state quantum computers, interactions between qubits are limited to a small number of neighboring qubits. Taking into account this limitation we describe how quantum algorithms can be executed efficiently on these designs. We illustrate our results with the quantum Fourier transform for which linear depth networks are obtained. The concepts presented in this work can be applied to all quantum algorithms to reduce considerably the coherence time needed for their execution. © 2001 The American Physical Society.

Title: Optimally shaped terahertz pulses for phase retrieval in a Rydberg-atom data register
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rangan C., Physics Department, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States; Bucksbaum P.H., Physics Department, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States
Abstract: A terahertz pulse was designed to implement a search algorithm on a quantum data register. Phase information stored in a Rydberg wave packet was optimally retrieved through the interaction with the pulse. Careful attention was paid to the smooth switch on and switch off of the terahertz pulse. Furthermore, the possibility of designing an optimal pulse that can achieve not only a desired target state of an atom, but also implement a desired algorithm was shown.

Author full names: Labunets, V.G. (6701610877); Rundblad-Labunets, E.V. (7801405327); Astola, J. (35232592700)
Title: Fast quantum nD Fourier and Radon transforms
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Automat. and Info. Technol., Urals State Technical University, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Labunets V.G., Dept. of Automat. and Info. Technol., Urals State Technical University, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Rundblad-Labunets E.V., Dept. of Automat. and Info. Technol., Urals State Technical University, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Astola J., Dept. of Automat. and Info. Technol., Urals State Technical University, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Fast classical and quantum algorithms are introduced for a wide class of non-separable nD discrete unitary K-transforms (DKT)KN(n). They require a number of 1D DKT KN smaller than in the Cooley-Tukey radix-p FFT-type approach. The method utilizes a decomposition of the nD K-transform into a product of original nD Discrete Radon Transform and of a family parallel/independ 1D K-transforms. If the nD K-transform (for example, Discrete Fourier Transform) has a separable kernel, that again in this case our approach leads to decrease of multiplicative complexity by factor of n (where n is the dimension) compared to the row/column separable Cooley-Tukey p-radix approach.

Abstract: The quantum fourier transforms on Abelian groups was identified as a powerful tool for developing quantum algorithms. Fast fourier transforms (FFT) on finite albelian groups were widely used in signal processing. In classical signal processing a new classes of unitary transforms was started for possible applications. The harmonic analysis of functions on discrete one dimesional and n dimensional Heisenberg-wely groups and the Galois fields were also studied.

Abstract: Grover operators and Grover kernels were used to analyze quantum searching algorithms. Problem solving approach with Grover's algorithms was also presented. The constructions under perturbations of the initial conditions to a very general class of operators was discussed. The members of these parameter class were found to solve the searching algorithms.

Title: Relative number squeezing in Bose-Einstein condensates
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Clarendon Laboratory, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PU, Parks Road, United Kingdom; Department of Physics, Georgia Southern University, Statesboro, Georgia 30460-8031, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dunningham J.A., Clarendon Laboratory, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PU, Parks Road, United Kingdom; Burnett K., Clarendon Laboratory, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PU, Parks Road, United Kingdom; Edwards M., Department of Physics, Georgia Southern University, Statesboro, Georgia 30460-8031, United States
Abstract: Two condensate modes with resonant Raman pulses were used to create pairs of Bose-Einstein condensates with relative number squeezing. The effects of dissipation in the creation of quantum states with squeezed relative numbers were studied using quantum model. Linear equations were analyzed to evolve the influence of nonlinear intrinsic atomic interactions. The results of quantum simulations used to validate the semiclassical model efficiently predicted scaling for large numbers.

Title: Quantum database search can do without sorting
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: CTS and SERC, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Patel A., CTS and SERC, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India
Abstract: Sorting is a fundamental computational process that facilitates subsequent searching of a database. It can be thought of as factorization of the search process. The location of a desired item in a sorted database can be found by classical queries that inspect one letter of the label at a time. For an unsorted database, no such classical quick search algorithm is available. If the database permits quantum queries, however, then mere digitization is sufficient for efficient search. Sorting becomes redundant with the quantum superposition of states. A quantum algorithm is written down that locates the desired item in an unsorted database a factor of two faster than the best classical algorithm can in a sorted database. This algorithm has close resemblance to the assembly process in DNA replication. © 2001 The American Physical Society.

Title: Structural and thermodynamic properties of diamond: A path-integral Monte Carlo study
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales, Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas (C.S.I.C.), Campus de Cantoblanco, Madrid, 28049, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Herrero C.P., Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales, Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas (C.S.I.C.), Campus de Cantoblanco, Madrid, 28049, Spain; Ramírez R., Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales, Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas (C.S.I.C.), Campus de Cantoblanco, Madrid, 28049, Spain
Abstract: Path-integral Monte Carlo simulations in the isothermal-isobaric ensemble have been carried out to study structural and thermodynamic properties of diamond, as a function of temperature and hydrostatic pressure. Atomic nuclei were treated as quantum particles interacting through a Tersoff-type potential. The obtained lattice parameter, heat capacity, thermal expansion coefficient, and bulk modulus show an overall agreement with the experimental data. The importance of anharmonicity and quantum effects on the properties derived from the quantum simulations has been assessed by comparison with results obtained in classical simulations with the same interatomic potential, as well as with those derived from a quasiharmonic approximation. An increase in the lattice parameter by 1.7 × 10−2 Å and a decrease in the bulk modulus by about 5% is found at low temperatures, as a consequence of the zero-point motion of the C atoms. © 2001 American Physical Society.

Title: Quantum neurocomputation and signal processing
Source title: Neural Networks for Signal Processing - Proceedings of the IEEE Workshop
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eghbalnia Hamid, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Assadi Amir, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Quantum computational algorithm was studied to determine the closeness of a given signal to one of the sets previously observed signal stored in the state of a quantum neurocomputational machine. The realization of a new quantum algorithm for factorization of integers by Shor and its implications to cryptography were also studied. Neural networks (NN) provided a natural paradigm of parallel distributed processing of a wide class of signals. Quantum connections provided the realization of probability distribution over the set of states, which on combination with the quantum neurons provided a density matrix representation of the system.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Computer simulation; Data processing; Mathematical transformations; Neural networks; Probability distributions; Signal processing; Independent component analysis; Quantum Neurocomputation (QN); Quantum theory

Title: Quantum lower bounds by polynomials
Affiliations: University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, United States; CWI, University of Amsterdam, Amsterdam, Netherlands; University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta., Canada; University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada; University of Arizona, Department of Mathematics, Tucson, AZ 85721-0089, 617 North Santa Rita Avenue, United States; CWI, Amsterdam, P.O. Box 94079, Netherlands; Cleve R., University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta., Canada, Department of Computer Science, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada; Mosca M., University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada, Ctr. for Appl. Cryptographic Res., University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada; De Wolf R., CWI, University of Amsterdam, Amsterdam, Netherlands, CWI, Amsterdam, P.O. Box 94079, Netherlands
Abstract: We examine the number of queries to input variables that a quantum algorithm requires to compute Boolean functions on {0, } Nin the black-box model. We show that the exponential quantum speed-up obtained for partial functions (i.e., problems involving a promise on the input) by Deutsch and Jozsa, Simon, and Shor cannot be obtained for any total function: if a quantum algorithm computes some total Boolean function fwith small error probability using T black-box queries, then there is a classical deterministic algorithm that computes f exactly with O(T 6) queries. We also give asymptotically tight characterizations of T for all symmetric f in the exact, zero-error, and bounded-error settings. Finally, we give new precise bounds for AND, OR, and PARITY. Our results are a quantum extension of the so-called polynomial method, which has been successfully applied in classical complexity theory, and also a quantum extension of results by Nisan about a polynomial relationship between randomized and deterministic decision tree complexity.
Author Keywords: Black-box model; Lower bounds; Polynomial method; Quantum computing; Query complexity

Title: Improved quantum Fourier transform algorithm and applications
Source title: Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science - Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hales Lisa, Univ of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, United States; Hallgren Sean, Univ of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: We give an algorithm for approximating the quantum Fourier transform over an arbitrary Zp which requires only O(n log n) steps where n = log p to achieve an approximation to within an arbitrary inverse polynomial in n. This improves the method of Kitaev which requires time quadratic in n. This algorithm also leads to a general and efficient Fourier sampling technique which improves upon the quantum Fourier sampling lemma of [8]. As an application of this technique we give a quantum algorithm which finds the period of an arbitrary periodic function, i.e. a function which may be many-to-one within each period. We show that this algorithm is efficient (polylogarithmic in the period of the function) for a large class of periodic functions. Moreover, using standard quantum lower-bound techniques we show that this characterization is tight. That is, this is the maximal class of periodic functions with an efficient quantum period-finding algorithm.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Approximation theory; Computational complexity; Quantum theory; Theorem proving; Quantum Fourier transforms (QFT); Fourier transforms

Title: Magnetic and metal-insulator transitions through bandwidth control in two-dimensional Hubbard models with nearest and next-nearest neighbor transfers
Source title: Journal of the Physical Society of Japan
Affiliations: Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8581, 5-1-5 Kashiwanoha, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kashima T., Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8581, 5-1-5 Kashiwanoha, Japan; Imada M., Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8581, 5-1-5 Kashiwanoha, Japan
Abstract: Numerical studies on Mott transitions caused by the control of the ratio between bandwidth and electron-electron interaction (U) are reported. By using the recently proposed path-integral renormalization group (PIRG) algorithm, physical properties near the transitions in the ground state of two-dimensional half-filled models with the nearest and the next-nearest neighbor transfers (-t and t′, respectively) are studied as a prototype of geometrically frustrated system. The nature of the bandwidth-control transitions shows sharp contrast with that of the filling-control transitions: First, the metal-insulator and magnetic transitions are separated each other and the metal-insulator (MI) transition occurs at smaller U, although the both transition interactions U increase with increasing t′. Both transitions do not contradict the first-order transitions for smaller t′/t while the MI transitions become continuous type accompanied by emergence of unusual metallic phase near the transition for large t′/t. A nonmagnetic insulator phase is stabilized between MI and AF transitions. The region of the nonmagnetic insulator becomes wider with increasing t′/t. The phase diagram naturally connects two qualitatively different limits, namely the Hartree-Fock results at small t′/t and speculations in the strong coupling Heisenberg limit.

Authors: Olsen M.K.; Kruglov V.I.; Collett M.J.
Title: Effects of χ(3) nonlinearities in second-harmonic generation
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Auckland, Auckland, Private Bag 92019, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Olsen M.K., Department of Physics, University of Auckland, Auckland, Private Bag 92019, New Zealand; Kruglov V.I., Department of Physics, University of Auckland, Auckland, Private Bag 92019, New Zealand; Collett M.J., Department of Physics, University of Auckland, Auckland, Private Bag 92019, New Zealand
Abstract: We investigate the effects of higher-order, χ(3), nonlinearities on the process of second-harmonic generation. In the traveling-wave case we find substantive differences in the macroscopic behavior of the fields when the χ(3) components are present. In the intracavity case, which has been investigated before using a linearized analysis, we investigate regions where these analyses may not be valid, comparing and contrasting the full quantum simulations with previous results. ©2001 The American Physical Society.

Title: Quantum lattice-gas model for computational fluid dynamics
Source title: Physical Review E - Statistical Physics, Plasmas, Fluids, and Related Interdisciplinary Topics
Affiliations: Air Force Research Laboratory, MA, 01731, Hanscom Air Force Base, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yepez J., Air Force Research Laboratory, MA, 01731, Hanscom Air Force Base, United States
Abstract: Quantum-computing ideas are applied to the practical and ubiquitous problem of fluid dynamics simulation. Hence, this paper addresses two separate areas of physics: quantum mechanics and fluid dynamics (or specifically, the computational simulation of fluid dynamics). The quantum algorithm is called a quantum lattice gas. An analytical treatment of the microscopic quantum lattice-gas system is carried out to predict its behavior at the mesoscopic scale. At the mesoscopic scale, a lattice Boltzmann equation with a nonlocal collision term that depends on the entire system wave function, governs the dynamical system. Numerical results obtained from an exact simulation of a one-dimensional quantum lattice model are included to illustrate the formalism. A symbolic mathematical method is used to implement the quantum mechanical model on a conventional workstation. The numerical simulation indicates that classical viscous damping is not present in the one-dimensional quantum lattice-gas system. © 2001 The American Physical Society.

Title: Separating quantum and classical learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Division of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Servedio R.A., Division of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Abstract: We consider a model of learning Boolean functions from quantum membership queries. This model was studied in [26], where it was shown that any class of Boolean functions which is informationtheoretically learnable from polynomially many quantum membership queries is also information-theoretically learnable from polynomially many classical membership queries. In this paper we establish a strong computational separation between quantum and classical learning. We prove that if any cryptographic oneway function exists, then there is a class of Boolean functions which is polynomial-time learnable from quantum membership queries but not polynomial-time learnable from classical membership queries. A novel consequence of our result is a quantum algorithm that breaks a general cryptographic construction which is secure in the classical setting. © 2011 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Index Keywords: Automata theory; Boolean functions; Information theory; Polynomial approximation; Quantum theory; Computational linguistics; Cryptography; Membership query; One-way functions; Polynomial-time; Quantum algorithms; Quantum cryptography

Title: Quantum network optimization
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department de Physique, Universitë de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Que. J1K 2R1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Blais A., Department de Physique, Universitë de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Que. J1K 2R1, Canada
Abstract: An overview is given on improvements that should be applied in the implementation of quantum algorithms. To illustrate this, results for the important case of the quantum Fourier transform are presented. It is emphasized that quantum algorithms can be optimized by prior classical computation to yield networks necessitating much smaller coherence times. In addition, as long as they allow for simultaneous operations of distinct qubits, solid state quantum computers can be designed with very simple qubit-qubit interaction schemes without degrading their performance.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer applications; Fourier transforms; Optimization; Quantum network optimization; Solid state quantum computer; Quantum theory

Title: Quantum dynamics using pseudo-particle trajectories: a new approach based on the multiconfiguration time-dependent Hartree method
Affiliations: Theoretische Chemie, Physikalisch-Chemisches Institut, INF 229, D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Worth G.A., Theoretische Chemie, Physikalisch-Chemisches Institut, INF 229, D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: A trajectory based method is presented, where the equations of motion for the pseudo-particles are derived using a fully quantum-mechanical approximate solution to the time-dependent Schroedinger equation: the multi-configuration time-dependent Hartree (MCTDH) method. This method should enable new approaches to be developed for the accurate solution of the time-dependent Schroedinger equation for large systems, being able to adopt techniques from classical and quantum simulations.

Authors: Sadakane K.; Sugawara N.; Tokuyama T.
Author full names: Sadakane, Kunihiko (7005716583); Sugawara, Norito (7101902794); Tokuyama, Takeshi (7103368328)
Title: Quantum algorithms for intersection and proximity problems
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Graduate School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sadakane K., Graduate School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan; Sugawara N., Graduate School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan; Tokuyama T., Graduate School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan
Abstract: We discuss applications of quantum computation to geometric data processing. Especially, we give efficient algorithms for intersection problems and proximity problems. Our algorithms are based on Brassard et al.'s amplitude amplification method, and analogous to Buhrman et al.'s algorithm for element distinctness. Revealing these applications is useful for classifying geometric problems, and also emphasizing potential usefulness of quantum computation in geometric data processing. Thus, the results will promote research and development of quantum computers and algorithms. © 2001 Springer Berlin Heidelberg.

Title: A new kind of CNOT-gate implementation for information processing with trapped ions
Source title: Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics
Affiliations: Electronics Group at IESK, Otto-von-Guericke-University Magdeburg, 39016 Magdeburg, P.O. Box 4120, Germany; Electronics Group at TET, University of Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Appelstr. 9A, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Pahlke K., Electronics Group at IESK, Otto-von-Guericke-University Magdeburg, 39016 Magdeburg, P.O. Box 4120, Germany; Mathis W., Electronics Group at TET, University of Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Appelstr. 9A, Germany
Abstract: A sequence of laser pulses is presented to implement a new kind of CNOT-gate in an linear arrangement of trapped ions. This type of quantum gate enables the designer of quantum algorithms to "send information into the phonon bus" controlled by the information stored in one of the ions. Some simulation results are given to show the dynamics of the system during the gate implementation. The simulation gives information about the leakage and the gate accuracy.

Title: Quantum simulations of classical random walks and undirected graph connectivity
Source title: Journal of Computer and System Sciences
Affiliations: Departement d'informatique recherche, Université de Montréal, Montréal Que., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Watrous J., Departement d'informatique recherche, Université de Montréal, Montréal Que., Canada
Abstract: While it is straightforward to simulate a very general class of random processes space-efficiently by non-unitary quantum computations (e.g., quantum computations that allow intermediate measurements to occur), it is not currently known to what extent restricting quantum computations to be unitary affects the space required for such simulations. This paper presents a method by which a limited class of random processes-random walks on undirected graphs-can be simulated by unitary quantum computations in a space-efficient (and time-efficient) manner. By means of such simulations, it is demonstrated that the undirected graph connectivity problem for regular graphs can be solved by one-sided error quantum Turing machines that run in logspace and require a single measurement at the end of their computations. It follows that symmetric logspace is contained in a quantum analogue of randomized logspace that disallows intermediate measurements.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Error analysis; Graphic methods; Probabilistic logics; Problem solving; Random processes; Turing machines; Classical random walks; Quantum simulations; Quantum Turing machines; Randomized logspace; Undirected graph connectivity; Unitary quantum computations; Computer simulation

Authors: Dorrer C.; Londero P.; Anderson M.; Wallentowitz S.; Walmsley I.A.
Title: Computing with interference: All-optical single-query 50-element database search
Source title: Technical Digest - Summaries of Papers Presented at the Quantum Electronics and Laser Science Conference, QELS 2001
Affiliations: Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dorrer C., Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States; Londero P., Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States; Anderson M., Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States; Wallentowitz S., Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States; Walmsley I.A., Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States
Abstract: Summary form only given. Quantum information processing relies on interference and entanglement. Certain quantum algorithms have been demonstrated using interference alone. These have been criticized on the grounds that the number of resources they require does not scale favorably with the size of the database. Nonetheless it has been argued that algorithms implemented entirely using interference may be more efficient than algorithms implemented on classical particle-based machines. © 2001 Optical Soc. Of America.

Title: Quantum arithmetic coding
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory - Proceedings
Affiliations: IBM Almaden Research Center, San Jose, CA 95120, 650 Harry Road, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chuang I.-L., IBM Almaden Research Center, San Jose, CA 95120, 650 Harry Road, United States; Modha D.S., IBM Almaden Research Center, San Jose, CA 95120, 650 Harry Road, United States
Abstract: We study the problem of compressing a block of symbols (a block quantum state) emitted by a memoryless quantum Bernoulli source. We present a simple-to-implement quantum algorithm for projecting, with high probability, the block quantum state onto the typical subspace spanned by the leading eigenstates of its density matric. We propose a fixed-rate quantum Shannon-Fano code to compress the projected block quantum state using a per symbol code rate that is slightly higher than the von Neumann entropy limit. Finally, we propose quantum arithmetic codes to efficiently implement quantum Shannon-Fano codes.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Data compression; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Information theory; Matrix algebra; Probability; Quantum cryptography; Quantum arithmetic coding; Quantum data compression; Encoding (symbols)

Authors: Mussinger M.; Delgado A.; Alber G.
Author full names: Mussinger, Michael (6507004171); Delgado, Aldo (56238477400); Alber, Gernot (7005980208)
Title: Error avoiding quantum codes and dynamical stabilization of Grover's algorithm
Affiliations: Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Mussinger M., Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany; Delgado A., Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany; Alber G., Abteilung für Quantenphysik, Universität Ulm, D-89069 Ulm, Germany
Abstract: Dynamical stabilization properties of error avoiding quantum codes are investigated beyond the perturbative regime. As an example Grover's search algorithm and its behaviour under a particular class of coherent errors are studied. Numerical examples which demonstrate that error avoiding quantum codes may be capable of stabilizing quantum algorithms well beyond the regime for which they were designed originally are presented.

Authors: Hallgren S.; Russell A.; Ta-Shma A.
Author full names: Hallgren, Sean (6603804900); Russell, Alexander (7402736365); Ta-Shma, Amnon (6701381914)
Title: Normal subgroup reconstruction and quantum computation using group representations
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing
Affiliations: Computer Science Division, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT 06269, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hallgren S., Computer Science Division, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Russell A., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT 06269, United States; Ta-Shma A., Computer Science Division, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: The Hidden Subgroup Problem is the foundation of many quantum algorithms. An efficient solution is known for the problem over Abelian groups and this was used in Simon's algorithm and Shor's Factoring and Discrete Log algorithms. The non-Abelian case is open; an efficient solution would give rise to an efficient quantum algorithm for Graph Isomorphism. We fully analyze a natural generalization of the Abelian case solution to the non-Abelian case, and give an efficient solution to the problem for normal subgroups. We show, however, that this immediate generalization of the Abelian algorithm does not efficiently solve Graph Isomorphism. © 2000 ACM.

Title: Efficient quantum computing of complex dynamics

Abstract: A realistic quantum computer was used to simulate with exponential efficiency complex dynamics with rich phase space structures. It was demonstrated that the main structures inside the localization domain are rather stable in the presence of static imperfections. Errors from static imperfections were stronger than the errors of noisy gates.

Authors: Ortiz G.; Gubernatis J.E.; Knill E.; Laflamme R.
Title: Quantum algorithms for fermionic simulations
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ortiz G., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Gubernatis J.E., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Knill E., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Laflamme R., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: The implementation of algorithms for the simulation of fermionic quantum systems was studied. An explicit mapping that relates the usual qubit of a quantum computer to the fermionic modes to be simulated was given. Focus was on the so-called dynamical sign problem. It was shown that this problem is avoided in quantum computing simulation.

Title: Can quantum chaos enhance the stability of quantum computation?
Source title: Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General
Affiliations: Physics Department, Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Prosen T., Physics Department, Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Žnidarič M., Physics Department, Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: We consider the stability of a general quantum algorithm (QA) with respect to a fixed but unknown residual interaction between qubits, and show a surprising fact, namely that the average fidelity of quantum computation increases on decreasing the average time correlation function of the perturbing operator in sequences of consecutive quantum gates. Our thinking is applied to the quantum Fourier transformation, where an alternative 'less regular' QA is devised, which is qualitatively more robust against static random residual n-qubit interaction.

Title: Efficient factorization with a single pure qubit and log N mixed qubits
Affiliations: Optics Section, Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London SW7 2BW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Parker S., Optics Section, Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London SW7 2BW, United Kingdom; Plenio M.B., Optics Section, Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London SW7 2BW, United Kingdom
Abstract: A study is carried out to demonstrate that a single pure qubit, together with an initial supply of log2N qubits in an arbitrarily mixed state, is sufficient to implement Shor's algorithm for the factorization of the number N efficiently. The efficiency of the modified algorithm is shown to be essentially independent of the degree of mixing of the log2N qubits.

Title: Multilevel quantum logic in Fourier conjugate bases
Affiliations: The Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Muthukrishnan A., The Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States; Stroud C.R., Jr., The Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, 14627, NY, United States
Abstract: Current schemes for implementing quantum logic involve controlled coupling between two-level systems, or qubits, which requires a large number of qubits to be entangled coherently for information processing. A multilevel basis for quantum information minimizes the number of systems that need to be entangled. We present the requirements for multilevel quantum logic in a dual basis formalism that emphasizes the key role played by the Fourier transform in quantum algorithms. We discuss a realization in atomic systems, where the two bases consist of energy levels and wave packets, and examine the practical resources needed for controlling each basis. © 2001 OSA/ICQI 2001.

Title: Stable quantum computation of unstable classical chaos
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, UMR 5626 du CNRS, Université Paul Sabatier, F-31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Authors with affiliations: Georgeot B., Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, UMR 5626 du CNRS, Université Paul Sabatier, F-31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France; Shepelyansky D.L., Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, UMR 5626 du CNRS, Université Paul Sabatier, F-31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Abstract: A simulation method for classical chaotic system with exponential efficiency on a quantum computer was presented. The classical errors growing exponentially with time as a result of chaos were also analyzed. It was found that quantum algorithms with some imperfections can successfully reproduce the time evolution in the classical phase space for moderate quantum errors. It was found that in a few qubit systems the quantum algorithm can be easily implemented.

Title: Discrete Wigner functions and the phase space representation of quantum computers
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: Departamento de Física j.J. Giambiagi, FCEN, UBA, 1428 Buenos Aires, Pabellón 1, Ciudad Universitaria, Argentina; Unidad de Actividad Física, Tandar, CNEA, Buenos Aires, Argentina

Giambiagi, FCEN, UBA, 1428 Buenos Aires, Pabellón 1, Ciudad Universitaria, Argentina; Paz J.P., Departamento de Física j.J. Giambiagi, FCEN, UBA, 1428 Buenos Aires, Pabellón 1, Ciudad Universitaria, Argentina; Saraceno M., Unidad de Actividad Física, Tandar, CNEA, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Abstract: We show how to represent the state and the evolution of a quantum computer (or any system with an N-dimensional Hilbert space) in phase space. For this purpose we use a discrete version of the Wigner function which, for arbitrary N, is defined in a phase space grid of 2N × 2N points. We compute such Wigner function for states which are relevant for quantum computation. Finally, we discuss properties of quantum algorithms in phase space and present the phase space representation of Grover’s quantum search algorithm. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

Abstract: We have developed a quantum simulation tool to investigate transport in molecular structures. The method is based on the joint use of a Density functional tight-binding (DFTB) and of a Green's function technique which allows us the calculation of current flow through the investigated structures. Typical calculations are shown for carbon-nanotube-based field effect transistors, sensors and for DNA fragments. © 2002, Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Abstract: Quantum walks are expected to provide useful algorithmic tools for quantum computation. This paper introduces absorbing probability and time of quantum walks and gives both numerical simulation results and theoretical analyses on Hadamard walks on the line and symmetric walks on the hypercube from the viewpoint of absorbing probability and time. Our results may be suggestive in constructing efficient quantum algorithms for combinatorial problems such as SAT. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2002.
