Title: On the distinction between entangled and separable states of quantum registers
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Nanotechnology
Affiliations: Leibniz Laboratory, Grenoble, France
Authors with affiliations: Jorrand P., Leibniz Laboratory, Grenoble, France; Mhalla M., Leibniz Laboratory, Grenoble, France
Abstract: Quantum computing operates in three stages: (i) preparation of the initial states of the n qubits of a register, (ii) step by step transformation of the state of this register by unitary operators which compose the quantum program, and (iii), measurement of all or some of the qubits of the register. The existence of quantum algorithms which are exponentially less complex than their classical counterparts for some classes of problems, stems from entangled states established by multi-qubit unitary operators within the quantum program. A register of n qubits is a quantum system composed of n quantum subsystems. The state |ψ> of a quantum system composed of two quantum subsystems A and B is said to be entangled when |ψ> is not reducible to a pair composed of a state |ψA> of A and a state |ψB> of B: such situations have no counterpart in the classical world. In quantum theory, such a pair of states is denoted by a tensor product: |ψ> is entangled if it cannot be factorized into the tensor product |ψA>⊗|ψB>. This paper establishes conditions according to which it is possible to tell whether or not the state of a register of n qubits is entangled. The state of a single qubit is a vector α|0>+β|1> of unit norm in a 2-dimensional vector space, where |0> and |1> are the two basis states and where a and are complex amplitudes. Then, if both A and B are qubits, the most general form of the state of a register composed of the 2 qubits A and B is also a vector of unit norm, but now in a 4-dimensional space: |ψ>=α|00>+β|01>+γ|10>+σ|11>. It is straightforward to prove that |ψ> can be factorized into |ψA>⊗|ψB> if and only if αδ=βγ. In such a case, |ψ> is said to be separable, i.e. not entangled. This paper generalizes this form of condition to registers of n qubits. If |ψ> is the state of a register of n qubits, two different questions about the separability of |ψ> are answered: (i) is |ψ> separable into a product |ψ1>⊗|ψ2>⊗L⊗|ψn> of n single qubit states? and (ii), is |ψ> separable into a product |ψA>⊗|ψB> of the states of two subregisters A and B, respectively containing p and q adjacent qubits with p+q=n? For both questions, necessary and sufficient conditions are given. © 2002 IEEE.

Title: A quantum perceptron
Source title: International Journal of Modern Physics B
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Lethbridge, Lethbridge, Alta. T1K 3M4, 4401 University Drive, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Andrecut M., Department of Physics, University of Lethbridge, Lethbridge, Alta. T1K 3M4, 4401 University Drive, Canada; Ali M.K., Department of Physics, University of Lethbridge, Lethbridge, Alta. T1K 3M4, 4401 University Drive, Canada
Abstract: The task of a classical perceptron is to classify two classes of patterns by generating a separation hyperplane. Here, we give a complete description of a quantum perceptron. The quantum algorithms for classification and learning are formulated in terms of unitary quantum gates operators. In the quantum case, the concept of separable or non-separable classes is irrelevant because the quantum perceptron can learn a superposition of patterns which are not separable by a hyperplane.

Authors: Tsai I.-M.; Kuo S.-Y.; Wei D.S.L.
Title: Quantum Boolean circuit approach for searching an unordered database
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Nanotechnology
Affiliations: Dept. of Electr. Eng., Nat. Taiwan Univ., Taipei, Taiwan; Department of Computer and Information Science, Fordham University, Bronx, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tsai I.-M., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Nat. Taiwan Univ., Taipei, Taiwan; Kuo S.-Y., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Nat. Taiwan Univ., Taipei, Taiwan; Wei D.S.L., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Nat. Taiwan Univ., Taipei, Taiwan, Department of Computer and Information Science, Fordham University, Bronx, NY, United States
Abstract: The discovery of polynomial time prime factorization, secure key distribution, and fast database search algorithm have recently made quantum computing the most rapidly expanding research field. For a quantum algorithm to be useful, it is essential that the algorithm can be implemented using quantum circuits. Nanotechnology, in particular quantum mechanics based devices, can be used to realize such an algorithm. In this paper, we show how quantum Boolean circuits can be used to implement the oracle circuit and the inversion-about-average function in Grover's search algorithm. We also show that a slight modification of the oracle circuit can be used to search multiple targets. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: De Graaf M.; De Wolf R.
Author full names: De Graaf, Mart (8937476000); De Wolf, Ronald (6701691445)
Title: On quantum versions of the yao principle
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: CWI, P.O. Box 94079, Amsterdam, 1090GB, Netherlands; UC Berkeley, 583 Soda Hall, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: De Graaf M., CWI, P.O. Box 94079, Amsterdam, 1090GB, Netherlands; De Wolf R., UC Berkeley, 583 Soda Hall, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States
Abstract: The classical Yao principle states that the complexity R∈(f) of an optimal randomized algorithm for a function f with success probability1 - e equals the complexity max„ D∈μ(f) of an optimal deterministic algorithm for f that is correct on a fraction 1 - ∈ of the inputs, weighed according to the hardest distribution μ over the inputs. In this paper we investigate to what extent such a principle holds for quantum algorithms. We propose two natural candidate quantum Yao principles, a “weak” and a “strong” one. For both principles, we prove that the quantum bounded-error complexityis a lower bound on the quantum analogues of max„ D∈μ(f). We then prove that equalitycannot be obtained for the “strong” version, byexhibiting an exponential gap. On the other hand, as a positive result we prove that the “weak” version holds up to a constant factor for the querycomplexityof all symmetric Boolean functions. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2002.

Title: Simulation of chaos-assisted tunneling in a semiclassical regime on existing quantum computers
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, Université Paul Sabatier, Toulouse Cedex 4, 31062, France; Lycée Pierre de Fermat, Parvis des Jacobins, Toulouse Cedex 7, 31068, France

Abstract: We present a quantum algorithm that allows one to simulate chaos-assisted tunneling in deep semiclassical regime on existing quantum computers. This opens additional possibilities for investigation of macroscopic quantum tunneling and realization of semiclassical Schrödinger cat oscillations [E. Schrödinger, Naturwissenschaften 32, 807 (1935)]. Our numerical studies determine the decoherence rate induced by noisy gates for these oscillations and propose a suitable parameter regime for their experimental implementation. 5555 2002 The American Physical Society.

Title: Fractally-structured CMOS processor for quantum-circuit emulation
Source title: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics, Part 1: Regular Papers and Short Notes and Review Papers
Affiliations: School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, 7-3-1 Hongo, Japan; School of Frontier Sciences, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, 7-3-1 Hongo, Japan; CREST, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, 7-3-1 Hongo, Japan

Abstract: A novel complementary-metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) processor labelled quantum-circuit processor (QCP) for the high-performance emulation of quantum computing is presented. The QCP performs the emulation of the calculation performed in the quantum circuit by simple matrix calculations based on single-instruction-stream-multiple-data-stream (SIMD) parallel processing. Using the parallel operation of an enormous number of devices in LSI, it executes quantum algorithms at a speed comparable to that of the quantum computer. A 5-qubit processor was implemented using a programmable logic device (PLD), and the quantum Fourier transformation was demonstrated by this processor. © 2002 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.

Title: Efficient Classical Simulation of Continuous Variable Quantum Information Processes
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Centre for Advanced Computing–Algorithms and Cryptography, Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia; Informatics Bangor University, Bangor, LL57 1UT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bartlett S.D., Department of Physics and Centre for Advanced Computing–Algorithms and Cryptography, Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia; Sanders B.C., Department of Physics and Centre for Advanced Computing–Algorithms and Cryptography, Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia; Braunstein S.L., Informatics Bangor University, Bangor, LL57 1UT, United Kingdom; Nemoto K., Informatics Bangor University, Bangor, LL57 1UT, United Kingdom
Abstract: We obtain sufficient conditions for the efficient simulation of a continuous variable quantum algorithm or process on a classical computer. The resulting theorem is an extension of the Gottesman-Knill theorem to continuous variable quantum information. For a collection of harmonic oscillators, any quantum process that begins with unentangled Gaussian states, performs only transformations generated by Hamiltonians that are quadratic in the canonical operators, and involves only measurements of canonical operators (including finite losses) and suitable operations conditioned on these measurements can be simulated efficiently on a classical computer. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Title: Quantum computing and a unified approach to fast unitary transforms
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: City University of New York, University of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, United States; Texas A and M University, Department of Computer Science, College Station, TX 77843-3112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Agaian S.S., City University of New York, University of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, United States; Klappenecker A., Texas A and M University, Department of Computer Science, College Station, TX 77843-3112, United States
Abstract: A quantum computer directly manipulates information stored in the state of quantum mechanical systems. The available operations have many attractive features but also underly severe restrictions, which complicate the design of quantum algorithms. We present a divide-and-conquer approach to the design of various quantum algorithms. The class of algorithm includes many transforms which are well-known in classical signal processing applications. We show how fast quantum algorithms can be derived for the discrete Fourier transform, the Walsh-Hadamard transform, the Slant transform, and the Hartley transform. All these algorithms use at most O(log2 N) operations to transform a state vector of a quantum computer of length N. © 2002 SPIE · 0277-786X/02/$15.00.

Title: Polynomial-time quantum algorithms for Pell's equation and the principal ideal problem
Source title: Conference Proceedings of the Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Caltech, Pasadena, CA 91125, MC 256-80, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hallgren S., Computer Science Department, Caltech, Pasadena, CA 91125, MC 256-80, United States
Abstract: We give polynomial-time quantum algorithms for two problems from computational algebraic number theory. The first is Pell's equation. Given a positive non-square integer d, Pell's equation is x2 - dy2 = 1 and the goal is to find its integer solutions. Factoring integers reduces to finding integer solutions of Pell's equation, but a reduction in the other direction is not known and appears more difficult. The second problem is the principal ideal problem in real quadratic number fields. Solving this problem is at least as hard as solving Pell's equation, and is the basis of a cryptosystem which is broken by our algorithm.
Index Keywords: Computation theory; Cryptography; Number theory; Polynomials; Problem solving; Quantum theory; Computational algebraic number theory; Factoring integers; Pell equation; Polynomial time quantum algorithms; Principal ideal problem; Algorithms

Authors: Benenti G.; Casati G.; Montangero S.; Shepelyansky D.L.
Title: Eigenstates of an operating quantum computer: Hypersensitivity to static imperfections
Affiliations: Unità di Como, Ist. Naz. per la Fis. della Materia, Univ. degli Studi dell'Insubria, 22100 Como, Via Valleggio 11, Italy; Ist. Naz. per la Fis. della Materia, Univ. degli Studi dell'Insubria, 22100 Como, Via Valleggio 11, Italy, Ist. Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Milano, 20133 Milano, Via Celoria 16, Italy; Montangero S., Unità di Como, Ist. Naz. per la Fis. della Materia, Univ. degli Studi dell'Insubria, 22100 Como, Via Valleggio 11, Italy; Shepelyansky D.L., Laboratoire de Physique Quantique, Université Paul Sabatier, 31062 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Abstract: We study the properties of eigenstates of an operating quantum computer which simulates the dynamical evolution in the regime of quantum chaos. Even if the quantum algorithm is polynomial in number of qubits nq, it is shown that the ideal eigenstates become mixed and strongly modified by static imperfections above a certain threshold which drops exponentially with nq. Above this threshold the quantum eigenstate entropy grows linearly with nq but the computation remains reliable during a time scale which is polynomial in the imperfection strength and in nq.

Authors: Goasguen S.; Butt A.R.; Colby K.D.; Lundstrorn M.S.
Title: Parallelization of the nanoscale device simulator nanoMOS-2.0 using a 100 nodes linux cluster
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Nanotechnology
Affiliations: Purdue University, 1285 Electrical Engineering Building, West Lafayette, 47907-1285, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goasguen S., Purdue University, 1285 Electrical Engineering Building, West Lafayette, 47907-1285, IN, United States; Butt A.R., Purdue University, 1285 Electrical Engineering Building, West Lafayette, 47907-1285, IN, United States; Colby K.D., Purdue University, 1285 Electrical Engineering Building, West Lafayette, 47907-1285, IN, United States; Lundstrorn M.S., Purdue University, 1285 Electrical Engineering Building, West Lafayette, 47907-1285, IN, United States
Abstract: A state of the art linux cluster is used for quantum simulations of nanoscale devices. The simulator, nanoMOS-2.0 was modified to speed up the energy integration by distributing the energy grid over several processors. An 88% speed-up was achieved using the Parallel Matlab Interface (PMI). A detailed scattering model was also implemented using the Parallel Virtual Machine (PVM) toolkit under Matlab. Near-linear scaling was obtained, allowing self-consistent simulations to be performed in a day using 40 processors instead of a predicted 40 days on a single processor machine. The simulator can be accessed through the nanoHUB, (http://www.nanohub.purdue.edu) which uses the network computing platform, PUNCH, which interoperates with the cluster through the Portable Batch System (PBS). © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Niwa J.; Matsumoto K.; Imai H.
Author full names: Niwa, Jumpei (7005714195); Matsumoto, Keiji (55471179300); Imai, Hiroshi (36348118200)
Title: General-purpose parallel simulator for quantum computing
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-0033, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Japan; ERATO, Project Quantum Computation and Information, Tokyo, JST Daini Hongo White Building 201, 5-28-3 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Niwa J., Department of Computer Science, Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-0033, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Japan; Matsumoto K., ERATO, Project Quantum Computation and Information, Tokyo, JST Daini Hongo White Building 201, 5-28-3 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Japan; Imai H., Department of Computer Science, Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-0033, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Japan, ERATO, Project Quantum Computation and Information, Tokyo, JST Daini Hongo White Building 201, 5-28-3 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Japan
Abstract: With current technologies, it seems to be very difficult to implement quantum computers with many qubits. It is therefore of importance to simulate quantum algorithms and circuits on the existing computers. However, for a large-size problem, the simulation often requires more computational power than is available from sequential processing. Therefore, simulation methods for parallel processors are required. We have developed a general-purpose simulator for quantum algorithms/circuits on the parallel computer (Sun Enterprise4500). It can simulate algorithms/circuits with up to 30 qubits. In order to test efficiency of our proposed methods, we have simulated Shor’s factorization algorithm and Grover’s database search, and we have analyzed robustness of the corresponding quantum circuits in the presence of both decoherence and operational errors. The corresponding results, statistics, and analyses are presented in this paper. 5555 2002 The American Physical Society.

Title: Family of sure-success quantum algorithms for solving a generalized grover search problem
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-4242, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hu C.-R., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-4242, United States
Abstract: The method to solve the generalized Grover search problem was discussed by using an infinite family of sure-success quantum algorithms. The two phase parameters were adjusted for each member of the family to ensure its sure success. The result showed that the algorithm were particularly useful when the cost of failure of a search was very high and for multistage searches with different search criterion for each stage.

Authors: Høyer P.; Neerbek J.; Shi Y.
Author full names: Høyer, Peter (56249296600); Neerbek, Jan (6506048599); Shi, Yaoyun (7404964334)
Title: Quantum complexities of ordered searching, sorting, and element distinctness
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada; Department of Computer Science, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Århus C, Denmark; Department of Computer Science, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Høyer P., Department of Computer Science, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada; Neerbek J., Department of Computer Science, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Århus C, Denmark; Shi Y., Department of Computer Science, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Abstract: We consider the quantum complexities of the following three problems: searching an ordered list, sorting an un-ordered list, and deciding whether the numbers in a list are all distinct. Letting N be the number of elements in the input list, we prove a lower bound of (1/π) (ln(N)-1) accesses to the list elements for ordered searching, a lower bound of Ω (N log N) binary comparisons for sorting, and a lower bound of Ω (√N log N) binary comparisons for element distinctness. The previously best known lower bounds are 1/12 log2(N) - O(1) due to Ambainis, Ω(N), and Ω(√N), respectively. Our proofs are based on a weighted all-pairs inner product argument. In addition to our lower bound results, we give an exact quantum algorithm for ordered searching using roughly 0.631 log2(N) oracle accesses. Our algorithm uses a quantum routine for traversing through a binary search tree faster than classically, and it is of a nature very different from a faster exact algorithm due to Farhi, Goldstone, Gutmann, and Sipser.

Title: Majorization arrow in quantum-algorithm design

Abstract: Efficient quantum algorithms are rare as compared with classical counterparts. In this article, evidence for the parallel idea that there is a majorization principle acting step by step during the time evolution in efficient quantum algorithms is outlined.

Title: Full Quantum Simulation of Silicon-on-Insulator Single-Electron Devices
Affiliations: Integrated Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum, Gloriastrasse 35, Zürich, CH-8092, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Heinz F.O., Integrated Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum, Gloriastrasse 35, Zürich, CH-8092, Switzerland; Schenk A., Integrated Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum, Gloriastrasse 35, Zürich, CH-8092, Switzerland; Scholze A., Integrated Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum, Gloriastrasse 35, Zürich, CH-8092, Switzerland; Fichtner W., Integrated Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum, Gloriastrasse 35, Zürich, CH-8092, Switzerland
Abstract: We present a method which extends the range of applicability of the domain decomposition approach to tunneling transport. Thereby we gain the ability to simulate e.g. structures with geometrically confined semiconductor quantum dots surrounded by very thin layers of dielectric or quantum dots that are defined through a combination of electrostatic forces and geometric confinement. Recently, experimental data of single electron devices on the 10 nm length-scale have become available, but due to the smallness of the devices detailed information on their geometry is hard to come by. Thus the simulations presented in this paper are intended as proof of principle rather than quantitative results for a real device. For predictive simulations more detailed knowledge of the experimental geometry is required. © 2002, Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Title: The near UV emission spectra of the LI*He excimers: Experimental and theoretical studies
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Düsseldorf, D40225 Düsseldorf, Universitätstr. 1, Germany; Institut für Physikalische Chemie und Elektrochemie, Universität Düsseldorf, D40225 Düsseldorf, Germany; Institute of Experimental Physics, University of Warsaw, 00-681 Warszawa, ul. Hoza69, Poland; Lehrstuhl für Theoretische Chemie, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D44780 Bochum, Universitätsstr. 150, Germany; Cable and Wireless Deutschland GmbH, D40221 Düsseldorf, Kaistr. 5, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Behmenburg W., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Düsseldorf, D40225 Düsseldorf, Universitätstr. 1, Germany; Kaiser A., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Düsseldorf, D40225 Düsseldorf, Universitätstr. 1, Germany, Cable and Wireless Deutschland GmbH, D40221 Düsseldorf, Kaistr. 5, Germany; Bettermann H., Institut für Physikalische Chemie und Elektrochemie, Universität Düsseldorf, D40225 Düsseldorf, Germany; Grycuk T., Institute of Experimental Physics, University of Warsaw, 00-681 Warszawa, ul. Hoza69, Poland; Staemmler V, Lehrstuhl für Theoretische Chemie, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D44780 Bochum, Universitätsstr. 150, Germany
Abstract: The emission transitions 3(D, P, S)∧ ′ → 2SΣ of the Li*He excimer which produce two diffuse bands in the 320-430 nm region have been studied experimentally for the first time using two-step laser excitation of a Li + He gas mixture in a cell. In addition, quantum simulations of these spectra have been performed by employing potential energy curves and oscillator strength functions of the LiHe molecule derived from ab initio methods. By means of the theoretical calculations a detailed understanding of the observed spectral features could be obtained. It was found that the simulations reproduce the observed spectra fairly well. However, the experimental positions of the two bands are red shifted by 100 and 250 cm-1, respectively, relative to the calculated ones. Reasons for this disagreement are discussed in terms of possible inaccuracies of the experimental and theoretical data, as well as possible deviations from thermal equilibrium among the fluorescence emitting states.
Index Keywords: Band structure; Computer simulation; Electron transitions; Emission spectroscopy; Fluorescence; Lithium compounds; Mixtures; Potential energy; Ultraviolet spectroscopy; Laser excitations; Excimer lasers

Title: The role of super-fast transforms in speeding up quantum computations
Source title: Proceedings of The International Symposium on Multiple-Valued Logic
Affiliations: McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zilic Z., McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada; Radecka K., McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada
Abstract: We present the role that spectral methods play in the development of the most impressive quantum algorithms, such as the polynomial time number factoring algorithm by Shor. While the fast transform algorithms reduce the number of operations needed in obtaining the transforms from O(22n) to O(n2n), quantum transforms are in comparison super-fast. The Quantum Fourier Transform can be performed in O(n2) time, while the specific cases of Walsh-Hadamard and Chrestenson Transforms require only O(n) operations. We derive Quantum Fourier Transform over non-binary quantum digits using the Chrestenson gate, which can serve as a basic block for quantum transforms.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Fast Fourier transforms; Many valued logics; Polynomials; Quantum algorithms; Quantum computation; Super fast transforms; Quantum theory

Title: Matter-Wave Interferometer for Large Molecules
Affiliations: Universität Wien, Institut für Experimentalphysik, Wien, A-1090, Boltzmanngasse 5, Austria

Abstract: We demonstrate a near-field Talbot-Lau interferometer for [Formula presented] fullerene molecules. Such interferometers are particularly suitable for larger masses. Using three free-standing gold gratings of [Formula presented] period and a transversally incoherent but velocity-selected molecular beam, we achieve an interference fringe visibility of [Formula presented] with high count rate. Both the high visibility and its velocity dependence are in good agreement with a quantum simulation that takes into account the van der Waals interaction of the molecules with the gratings and are in striking contrast to a classical moiré model. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Wellard C.; Hollenberg L.C.L.; Pauli H.C.
Title: Nonadiabatic controlled-NOT gate for the Kane solid-state quantum computer
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: School of Physics, University of Melbourne, Melbourne 3010, Australia; Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg D69029, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wellard C., School of Physics, University of Melbourne, Melbourne 3010, Australia; Hollenberg L.C.L., School of Physics, University of Melbourne, Melbourne 3010, Australia, Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg D69029, Germany; Pauli H.C., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg D69029, Germany
Abstract: An effective Hamiltonian that describes the interaction of the qubits in the subspace of the electron ground state was developed using the method of iterated resolvent. This effective Hamiltonian was then used to derive a controlled-NOT gate that relies only on the evolution of the qubits that it generates, in combination with the single-qubit operations. This fact was then used to argue that the family of gates consisting of the free evolution of neighboring qubits for predetermined times, is a suitable alternative to the adiabatically constructed c-NOT gate for use in the implementation of quantum algorithms.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Electrons; Ground state; Hamiltonians; Iterative methods; Magnetic fields; Matrix algebra; Partial differential equations; Electron spit states; Kane solid-state quantum computer; Qubits; Schrodinger equation; Quantum theory

Title: Portfolios of quantum algorithms
Affiliations: Physics Department, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; HP Labs, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maurer S.M., Physics Department, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, HP Labs, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States; Hogg T., Physics Department, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Huberman B.A., Physics Department, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States
Abstract: A simple form of quantum portfolios, in which all available phase choices are evaluated simultaneously and independently for each trial, is considered. This quantum portfolio allows a simple further improvement by combining it with an amplitude amplification.

Authors: Childs A.M.; Farhi E.; Goldstone J.; Gutmann S.
Author full names: Childs, Andrew M. (7006719969); Farhi, Edward (7004921657); Goldstone, Jeffrey (7102216578); Gutmann, Sam (6602169345)
Title: Finding cliques by quantum adiabatic evolution
Affiliations: Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. Technol., Cambridge, MA, United States; Department of Mathematics, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Childs A.M., Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. Technol., Cambridge, MA, United States; Farhi E., Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. Technol., Cambridge, MA, United States; Goldstone J., Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. Technol., Cambridge, MA, United States; Gutmann S., Department of Mathematics, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States
Abstract: Quantum adiabatic evolution provides a general technique for the solution of combinatorial search problems on quantum computers. We present the results of a numerical study of a particular application of quantum adiabatic evolution, the problem of finding the largest clique in a random graph. An n-vertex random graph has each edge included with probability 1/2, and a clique is a completely connected subgraph. There is no known classical algorithm that finds the largest clique in a random graph with high probability and runs in a time polynomial in n. For the small graphs we are able to investigate (n ≤ 18), the quantum algorithm appears to require only a quadratic run time.
Author Keywords: Adiabatic evolution; Quantum algorithms; Quantum computation
Index Keywords: Graph algorithms; Graph structures; Quantum computers; Quantum theory; Adiabatic evolution; Combinatorial search; Connected Subgraph; High probability; Quantum algorithms; Random graphs; Runtimes; Time polynomials; Graph theory

Title: Modified Grover’s algorithm for an expectation-value quantum computer
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collins D., Department of Physics, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, 15213, United States
Abstract: The translation of Grover’s search algorithm from its standard version, designed for implementation on a single quantum system amenable to projective measurements, into one suitable for an ensemble of quantum computers, whose outputs are expectation values of observables on individual qubits, is described in detail. A filtering scheme, which effectively determines expectation values on a limited portion of the quantum state, is presented and used to locate a single item for searches involving more than one marked item. A truncated version of Grover’s algorithm, requiring fewer steps than the translated standard version but locating marked items just as successfully, is proposed. For quantum computational devices that only return expectation values, the truncated version is superior to its standard counterpart. This indicates that it is possible to modify quantum algorithms so as to reduce the required temporal resources by using the ensemble’s spatial resources. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Considering an n-qubit density operator to which Grover’s operation is applied M times, we expand it in powers of [Formula Presented] and derive its matrix element order by order under the [Formula Presented] limit. Calculating the matrix element up to the fifth-order term numerically, we investigate a region of [Formula Presented] (perturbative parameter), where the algorithm finds the correct item with a threshold of probability [Formula Presented] or more. It satisfies [Formula Presented] around [Formula Presented] and [Formula Presented] and this linear relation is applied to a wide range of [Formula Presented] approximately. This observation is similar to a result obtained by Bernstein and Vazirani concerning accuracy of quantum gates for general algorithms. We cannot investigate a quantum-to-classical phase transition of the algorithm, because it is outside the reliable domain of our perturbation theory. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Title: Three-dimensional analysis of the electronic structure of cylindrical vertical quantum dots
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Beckman Inst. for Adv. Sci./Technol., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Matagne P., Beckman Inst. for Adv. Sci./Technol., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Leburton J.-P., Beckman Inst. for Adv. Sci./Technol., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: We present a detailed analysis of single-electron charging effects in cylindrical vertical quantum dots (CVQD's). Emphasis is placed on three-dimensional (3D) device effects that induce appreciable features in the quantized electron spectrum and in the addition energy spectrum of CVQD's. A potential model based on a 3D analytical solution of the Poisson equation provides intuitive physical insight into the variation of the eigenspectrum as a function of the potential nonparabolicity. This analytical model is in good qualitative agreement with a fall 3D self-consistent quantum simulation of single-electron charging in quantized CVQD's based on the density-functional theory. Hence we show that the-spin sequences realized in filling the third and fourth electronic shells are a sensitive function of the potential nonparabolicity arising from the 3D CVQD geometry, and varying with applied gate bias. Within this "atomic shell" model, the addition energy spectrum reflects the influence of 3D device effects and is not necessarily a signature of a particular spin-filling sequence.
Index Keywords: article; calculation; electron; energy; geometry; mathematical analysis; mathematical model; quantum theory; spectroscopy; theory

Title: Hot-carrier relaxation and thermalization in quantum-cascade lasers: Phase coherence versus energy relaxation
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale Per La Fisica Della Materia (INFM), Torino, Italy; Dipartimento Di Fisica, Politecnico Di Torino, I-10129 Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi, 24, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Iotti R.C., Istituto Nazionale Per La Fisica Della Materia (INFM), Torino, Italy, Dipartimento Di Fisica, Politecnico Di Torino, I-10129 Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi, 24, Italy; Rossi F., Istituto Nazionale Per La Fisica Della Materia (INFM), Torino, Italy, Dipartimento Di Fisica, Politecnico Di Torino, I-10129 Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi, 24, Italy
Abstract: A global quantum simulation - steady state as well as ultrafast - of non-equilibrium carrier dynamics in semiconductor-based quantum-cascade lasers is presented. In particular, the interplay between phase coherence and energy-relaxation/dephasing processes is investigated and discussed. Our analysis shows that quantum corrections to the semiclassical scenario are minor and confirms the incoherent nature of steady-state charge transport in these structures. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electronic transport; Inter-subband devices
Index Keywords: Charge transfer; Coherent light; Hot carriers; Quantum electronics; Ultrafast phenomena; Quantum cascade lasers (QCL); Ultrafast carrier dynamics; Quantum well lasers

Authors: Angelsmark O.; Dahllöf V.; Jonsson P.
Author full names: Angelsmark, Ola (8386077800); Dahllöf, Vilhelm (6508014666); Jonsson, Peter (35468727800)
Title: Finite domain constraint satisfaction using quantum computation
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Computer and Information Science, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Angelsmark O., Department of Computer and Information Science, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden; Dahllöf V., Department of Computer and Information Science, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden; Jonsson P., Department of Computer and Information Science, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden
Abstract: We present a quantum algorithm for finite domain constraint solving, where the constraints have arity 2. It is complete and runs in O(([d/2])n/2) time, where d is size of the domain of the variables and n the number of variables. For the case of d = 3w e provide a method to obtain an upper time bound of O(8n/8) ≈ O(1.2968n). Also for d = 5 the upper bound has been improved. Using this method in a slightly different way we can decide 3-colourability in O(1.2185n) time. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2002.
Index Keywords: Quantum theory; Finite domain constraints; Quantum algorithms; Upper Bound; Upper time bounds; Quantum computers

Authors: Childs A.M.; Farhi E.; Preskill J.
Author full names: Childs, Andrew M. (7006719969); Farhi, Edward (57206429216); Preskill, John (6701594380)
Title: Robustness of adiabatic quantum computation
Source title: Physical Review A. Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Institute for Quantum Information, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States
Authors with affiliations: Childs A.M., Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Farhi E., Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Preskill J., Institute for Quantum Information, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States
Abstract: The fault tolerance of quantum computation has been studied by adiabatic evolution, which is a quantum algorithm for solving combinatorial search problems. An inherent robustness of adiabatic computation against unitary control errors and decoherence is described. Fault tolerant protocols are necessary for the operation of quantum computers as these are more prone to errors as compared to classical digital computers.

Title: Introduction to solid-state quantum computation for engineers
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Centre for Biomedical Engineering, Adelaide University, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Ng J., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Centre for Biomedical Engineering, Adelaide University, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia; Abbott D., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Centre for Biomedical Engineering, Adelaide University, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia
Abstract: This review is an introduction to solid state quantum computation and its applications for engineers with little or no quantum physics background. Some current classical limits of computation are briefly described, and examples of quantum algorithms are presented to show why quantum computation may be a way of overcoming these limitations. In this review, we have focused on one quantum computer proposal, the Kane proposal. It is a solid-state proposal in silicon doped with 31P atoms. However, significant technological advances will be required in smart electronics, nanotechnology and solid state devices if we are to see a useful solid state quantum computer. © 2002 Published by Elsevier Science Ltd.
Author Keywords: Smart electronics; Smart structures and materials; Solid state quantum computation
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computation theory; Intelligent materials; Intelligent structures; Solid state physics; Quantum computation; Smart electronics; Quantum theory

Title: Quantum search by local adiabatic evolution
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique, Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roland J., Ecole Polytechnique, Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Cerf N.J., Ecole Polytechnique, Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, 1050, Belgium, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, 91109, United States
Abstract: The adiabatic theorem has been recently used to design quantum algorithms of a new kind, where the quantum computer evolves slowly enough so that it remains near its instantaneous ground state, which tends to the solution. We apply this time-dependent Hamiltonian approach to Grover’s problem, i.e., searching a marked item in an unstructured database. We find that by adjusting the evolution rate of the Hamiltonian so as to keep the evolution adiabatic on each infinitesimal time interval, the total running time is of order [Formula Presented] where N is the number of items in the database. We thus recover the advantage of Grover’s standard algorithm as compared to a classical search, scaling as N. This is in contrast with the constant-rate adiabatic approach of Farhi et al. (e-print quant-ph/0001106), where the requirement of adiabaticity is expressed only globally, resulting in a time of order N. © 2002 The American Physical Society.
